text: 1/ I became "CEO" at 20. I dropped out of college. I had only interned somewhere prev. Looking back, I couldn't imaÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/xXoEpEFtcS
full_text:
1/
I became "CEO" at 20. I dropped out of college. I had only interned somewhere prev. Looking back, I couldn't imagine the journey that would occur from writing code all day to scaling to 300 people. I got lucky, I screwed up a lot, & had a lot of help. Here's what I learned...

text: 2/ Giving up control is hard & it was the hardest for me. I felt like everything at the beginning was important. YoÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/a1Or8bQZam
full_text:
2/
Giving up control is hard & it was the hardest for me. I felt like everything at the beginning was important. You can't be good at everything tho. As you grow, I learned it's important to conciously give up things constantly. If you don't, you won't scale & everything suffers.

text: 3/ Your VCs won't want to offend you so I'll suggest it: get a CEO coach & do a 360 review of yourself every few yeÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/JYBR0N0anB
full_text:
3/
Your VCs won't want to offend you so I'll suggest it: get a CEO coach & do a 360 review of yourself every few years. It was life changing for me. You can’t fix everything about yourself. Focus on 2-3 things each year. Tell your company you’re doing it. It'll build trust.

text: 5/ Find a great mentor: Pick someone you want to impress. Find someone who will lift you up when you're down & takeÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/ThrMDVIwCW
full_text:
4/
Over time, you will feel like all you’re doing is spending time in meetings but not getting any real work done. You are though. Your job is now helping other people through the medium of meeting. Don't resist it, embrace it. Now's the time to design it to be fun & productive.

text: 4/ Over time, you will feel like all youÃ¢??re doing is spending time in meetings but not getting any real work done.Ã¢?Â¦ https://t.co/qnPhj3Ehim
full_text:
5/
Find a great mentor: Pick someone you want to impress. Find someone who will lift you up when you're down & take you down a notch when you're over confident. Ideally, they've been a CEO/founder before so they can empathize. Remember though: they offer guidance, not a script.

text: 6/ Live by the mantra: Ã¢??you should be building a team that can fulfill the mission without you.Ã¢?? You will be less sÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/42ogUutaA3
full_text:
6/
Live by the mantra: “you should be building a team that can fulfill the mission without you.” You will be less stressed in the long-run. Keep empowering others. When you forget, try & ask yourself why you started this thing in the first place. Was it really about $$/power/ego?

text: 8/ Don't avoid confrontation with tough, critical decisions--deal with it head-on. Avoiding confrontation, builds rÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/c0P0rN2XbZ
full_text:
7/
Power = responsibility. Being CEO will become lonely as you can't be as vulnerable & authentic as you'd like. Find other founders who will be real with you. Have dinners with them & share problems openly. I've been given hugs by them during tough times. It made the difference.

text: 7/ Power = responsibility. Being CEO will become lonely as you can't be as vulnerable & authentic as you'd like. FiÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/ala3aHRVQq
full_text:
8/
Don't avoid confrontation with tough, critical decisions--deal with it head-on. Avoiding confrontation, builds resentment over time, it slows the company down, & relationships eventually turn sour in a irrevocable way creating instability. Attack problems, not people though.

text: 9/ You will royally screw it up with people in your company even if it wasn't your decision. They may even dislikeÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/XrZX3TEpo9
full_text:
9/
You will royally screw it up with people in your company even if it wasn't your decision. They may even dislike *you* for a long time. The words “I am sorry. I screwed up.” are some of the most powerful words you can ever say to someone. It won’t always fix it though.

text: 10/ Your job will become 90% listening, 10% talking. I was bad at this & had to work 2x as hard at not interruptingÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/l6mMj5las4
full_text:
10/
Your job will become 90% listening, 10% talking. I was bad at this & had to work 2x as hard at not interrupting people. Best solution I found after 9.5 years was to write things down during a meeting. It made me focus on what they were saying & showed I was listening.

text: 11/ Your intuition about customers/the market will get worse as the organization grows & you become further estrangÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/6KqYyZ454b
full_text:
11/
Your intuition about customers/the market will get worse as the organization grows & you become further estranged from customers. Keep empowering others but hold them accountable. Spend time learning from them. Stick to the facts, not their opinions when making decisions.

text: 12/ Discovering the truth becomes hard as you grow. It also becomes the most important thing you can do as you guidÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/OkNqvjRWVt
full_text:
12/
Discovering the truth becomes hard as you grow. It also becomes the most important thing you can do as you guide the company. Make acquiring it & using it for decision a part of the culture somehow. I did this by constantly asking people what the actual facts were.

text: 13/ Control your mood meeting-to-meeting. Sometimes you will have a bad/devastating meeting but try to remember thaÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/RXJ1eqdQLI
full_text:
13/
Control your mood meeting-to-meeting. Sometimes you will have a bad/devastating meeting but try to remember that the next set of people don’t have that context & may be excited/stressed to meet with you.

text: 14/ WeÃ¢??re all human & have our insecurities so consider a therapist to assist in helping with your personal psycholÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/B4cDghCE7C
full_text:
14/
We’re all human & have our insecurities so consider a therapist to assist in helping with your personal psychology. If you associate a stigma with it know that I did too. I was wrong & wished I had done this earlier in life. It will be invaluable if you tend to bring it home.

text: 15/ Finally, keep working hard to improve. You canÃ¢??t fix mistakes of the past but you can be better in the future.Ã¢?Â¦ https://t.co/WK3Ls5BhkL
full_text:
15/
Finally, keep working hard to improve. You can’t fix mistakes of the past but you can be better in the future. Don't give up: when you make hard decisions, you get to know which values/principles you truly stand for. That alone makes the journey worth it. ✊

text: 2/ Ã¢??PMs are mini CEOsÃ¢??: This is admittedly a catchy tagline. CEOs have direct management responsibilities, decisionÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/isi7lQfdom
full_text:
1/
Product Management isn’t a major one can study, few folks graduate into, and most people learn by apprenticeship. There are number of dangerous myths about what the PM role is. Here is a thread with five…

text: 1/ Product Management isnÃ¢??t a major one can study, few folks graduate into, and most people learn by apprenticeshipÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/9MBaiWczd9
full_text:
2/
“PMs are mini CEOs”: This is admittedly a catchy tagline. CEOs have direct management responsibilities, decision making authority, business-level objective ownership, and often founder-level credibility for the original vision.

text: 3/ In reality, PMs have none of these. ItÃ¢??s a pernicious trap, because the PMs who act as if they are mini CEO forÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/6lIPr8dRur
full_text:
3/
In reality, PMs have none of these. It’s a pernicious trap, because the PMs who act as if they are mini CEO for a feature are the most likely candidates for a team organ rejection. Teammates want product leaders, not dictators.

text: 4/ Ã¢??PMs are the decision makersÃ¢??: Many people who convert from another role into product see it as way to get to Ã¢??mÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/6ibQWPuh7B
full_text:
4/
“PMs are the decision makers”: Many people who convert from another role into product see it as way to get to “make the calls”. It’s a common pattern, especially for disempowered engineers on dysfunctional product development teams.

text: 6/ That does not, however, mean they should make even a small fraction of decisions themselves. They should be theÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/WU5vos6CVa
full_text:
5/
PMs are responsible for the pace and quality of decision making. Full stop.

text: 5/ PMs are responsible for the pace and quality of decision making. Full stop.
full_text:
6/
That does not, however, mean they should make even a small fraction of decisions themselves. They should be the ultimate facilitator: pull the best ideas from their team, coordinate with xfn partners, get exec context, etc.

text: 7/ They should lay out well-researched tradeoffs, time-box deliberation, and structure great discussions.
full_text:
7/
They should lay out well-researched tradeoffs, time-box deliberation, and structure great discussions.

text: 8/ Only in rare situations should they actually Ã¢??make the callÃ¢??. When they do, it withdraws from their organizationÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/ImzX7CVZ9B
full_text:
8/
Only in rare situations should they actually “make the call”. When they do, it withdraws from their organizational capital account balance. That needs constant deposits as a counterbalance.

text: 11/ This has a two-fold downside: their team execution suffers without sufficient PM attention, and it stifles theÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/TvHANNW5nO
full_text:
9/
“PMs are the idea generators”: More than any other product dev role, PMs are judged nearly exclusively on the output of their team. Unlike eng or design, there are few independent artifacts to hang their hats on.

text: 9/ Ã¢??PMs are the idea generatorsÃ¢??: More than any other product dev role, PMs are judged nearly exclusively on the ouÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/FpzmLPaKsm
full_text:
10/
The degenerate case is PMs who think their ultimate work product is new ideas. They churn out 10x more concepts than their team could ever build.

text: 10/ The degenerate case is PMs who think their ultimate work product is new ideas. They churn out 10x more conceptsÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/7dveYmUyw1
full_text:
11/
This has a two-fold downside: their team execution suffers without sufficient PM attention, and it stifles the potential creativity from non-product teammates.

text: 15/ This requires developing deep domain knowledge, communicating compelling, and setting an inspirational strategy.
full_text:
12/
PMs do need to immerse themselves in context and research to prime coming up with great product ideas. In an ideal world, that’s a constant team exercise the PM just happens to drive.

text: 12/ PMs do need to immerse themselves in context and research to prime coming up with great product ideas. In an idÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/Ht99bYU9yb
full_text:
13/
“PMs have to be great at company politics”: Unfortunately, at the largest companies this one is a bit true. But at companies in the thousands or smaller, that degree of politics only happens when shared alignment breaks down.

text: 13/ Ã¢??PMs have to be great at company politicsÃ¢??: Unfortunately, at the largest companies this one is a bit true. ButÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/1mzLGofUNe
full_text:
14/
Great PMs are an antidote to startup politics emerging. They keep disparate groups bought into a shared vision of where the company/product needs to head.

text: 14/ Great PMs are an antidote to startup politics emerging. They keep disparate groups bought into a shared visionÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/l1dHcZB7f3
full_text:
15/
This requires developing deep domain knowledge, communicating compelling, and setting an inspirational strategy.

text: 18/ PMs do need to have a deep curiosity about the underlying tech, humility about the details, ability to developÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/39OhHvMfPJ
full_text:
16/
“PMs need technical degrees”: I believe this started with Google’s hiring of CS students directly into product, as a backlash of the MBA influx during the dot-com bubble. Though I was one of them, I disagree with the premise.

text: 19/ In summary, just a few dangerous PM myths to avoid: mini CEO, chief decision maker, primary idea generator, polÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/0twJ41tol7
full_text:
17/
While a technical foundation is certainly useful for PMs, like every hiring heuristic applied unconditionally as a filter it produces far too many false negatives.

text: 16/ Ã¢??PMs need technical degreesÃ¢??: I believe this started with GoogleÃ¢??s hiring of CS students directly into product,Ã¢?Â¦ https://t.co/nqo8khWeHw
full_text:
18/
PMs do need to have a deep curiosity about the underlying tech, humility about the details, ability to develop strong partnerships with engineering, and a voracious learning appetite.

text: 17/ While a technical foundation is certainly useful for PMs, like every hiring heuristic applied unconditionally aÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/20aH6AtDwF
full_text:
19/
In summary, just a few dangerous PM myths to avoid: mini CEO, chief decision maker, primary idea generator, political savant, and tech degree required.

full_text: ..."[after terraforming it] we'll wonder why, when we look at the land, we can never see anyting but our own faces." "Being the consciousness of the universe does not mean turning it all into a mirror image of us."

text: Five themes: 1. Scientific & aesthetic reasons not to terraform. 2. History of mars (age & processes) have value. 3Ã¢?Â¦ https://t.co/J7BjL8oNd0
full_text: Five themes: 1. Scientific & aesthetic reasons not to terraform. 2. History of mars (age & processes) have value. 3. Mars is independent of humans. 4. Mars shouldn't be turned into human artifact. 5. We need consistent environmental ethic across planets.

text: Theme1: Scientific/aesthetic. These are anthropocentric reasons, so (while good) are insufficient - they have to coÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/7qCcj18TFs
full_text: Theme1: Scientific/aesthetic. These are anthropocentric reasons, so (while good) are insufficient - they have to compete against other anthropocentric considerations.

text: But which historical processes/entities have value? Wilderness is about valuing ecological mechanisms that maintainÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/OFHbmgGzBD
full_text: Theme2: History Has Value. Origins of objects are part of their explanations - including wilderness' causal continuity with the past. (Argument prev used to compare natural areas to art.)

text: Theme2: History Has Value. Origins of objects are part of their explanations - including wilderness' causal continuÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/zkSnaku9Ez
full_text: But which historical processes/entities have value? Wilderness is about valuing ecological mechanisms that maintain landscape. Naturalness (unmodified by humans) is one factor in determining environmental value. We value forest/river b/c they represent world outside our dominion.

text: Autonomy: if an entity's existing/functioning is independent of us, then we should recognize it also has value independent on us.
full_text: Theme3: Mars independent of us (not for/because of us). Similar theme from philosophy: Non-Teleology. We value humans for independent (non-instrumental) existence, so for consistency, we should value non-human entities w/ independent existence.

text: Theme3: Mars independent of us (not for/because of us). Similar theme from philosophy: Non-Teleology. We value humaÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/yTbYtI2yse
full_text: Autonomy: if an entity's existing/functioning is independent of us, then we should recognize it also has value independent on us.

text: Theme4 (no mirror image/artifact): Follows from themes 2+3, because terraforming would destroy its causal continuitÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/ma0HiECVvN
full_text: Theme4 (no mirror image/artifact): Follows from themes 2+3, because terraforming would destroy its causal continuity with the processes that created it. We'd also destroy its autonomy (exists for self, not dependent on us).

text: Theme5 (consistent environmental ethic): Builds on last 4 themes, plus Aldo Leopold's Land Ethic: interdependence oÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/5o4lSxBNYM
full_text: Theme5 (consistent environmental ethic): Builds on last 4 themes, plus Aldo Leopold's Land Ethic: interdependence of biotic & abiotic elements. Buuuut, hard to apply that to an abiotic Mars.

text: But some of this Leopold fella's ideas apply. Conquerer role (colonialism) causes bad shit. Soil/water/etc should nÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/mBk7l6Z1P4
full_text: But some of this Leopold fella's ideas apply. Conquerer role (colonialism) causes bad shit. Soil/water/etc should not be seen as "resources" but as entities with right to continuous existence. On what basis should Mars be considered our resource?

text:
ThereÃ¢??s no such thing as a Ã¢??startup inside of a big company.Ã¢??

This misnomer actively misleads both big company empÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/dT0fNk5u1A
full_text:
There’s no such thing as a “startup inside of a big company.”
This misnomer actively misleads both big company employees working in such teams as well as people toiling in actual startups.
Despite all best efforts to create megacorp “startups”, they can never exist. Here's why:

text:
2) In the startup community, early-stage failure is often tolerated and even celebrated.

People understand what anÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/kIZpdgCKV3
full_text:
(And, by the way, I ran one of these “startups inside of a big company” myself and at the time thought it was basically a startup.
We had a cool name. We were small, lean, and agile and dreaming about the future and had a $50,000 3D printer. This was not a startup. I was wrong.)

text: 1) The most fundamental, pervasive background thread of an early-stage startup is that when it fails, everyone hasÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/MEAZMcST4c
full_text:
1)
The most fundamental, pervasive background thread of an early-stage startup is that when it fails, everyone has find a new job. The company is gone, kaput, relegated to the dustbin of Crunchbase.
The company literally lives & dies on the work every employee does every day.

text: On the other hand, early-stage work that any 20-person Ã¢??startupÃ¢?? team does inside of a 50,000 person company canÃ¢??tÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/MMJcR1NHtT
full_text:
On the other hand, early-stage work that any 20-person “startup” team does inside of a 50,000 person company can’t cause that entire company to fail.
The physics dictate that it is impossible. (It is also why some people prefer the stability of big company jobs, and that’s ok!)

text: In many big companies, on the other hand, taking a risk and failing often puts the stench of failure on the peopleÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/mbN9YujTbr
full_text:
2)
In the startup community, early-stage failure is often tolerated and even celebrated.
People understand what an accomplishment it is to have built a startup and are eager to hire people for a next gig. Failure is a badge of honor and is seen as eventually leading to success.

text: (And, by the way, I ran one of these Ã¢??startups inside of a big companyÃ¢?? myself and at the time thought it was basicÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/11N8KVVimI
full_text: In many big companies, on the other hand, taking a risk and failing often puts the stench of failure on the people who tried, leading to career stagnation at the hands of those who chose the “safer” path of sticking with the cash cows that are going to make money no matter what.

text: True story: We once wrapped an ethernet cable around the outside of our high-rise office building like a clotheslinÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/Z0niLSVr5Z
full_text:
3)
Big company “startups” start off with the existing infrastructure of a megacorp. The company provides snacks and drinks. Someone takes care of custodial, finding you office space, makes sure you have sweet conference rooms, benefits, hardware, access to software and services.

text:
In fact, in a big company Ã¢??startupÃ¢?? you often get the coolest space and the best perks.

Teams are set up in a Ã¢??garÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/K0crzW6fUd
full_text:
In fact, in a big company “startup” you often get the coolest space and the best perks.
Teams are set up in a “garage” or “innovation lab” decked out with modern amenities, cool showcase design elements, and state-of-the-art hardware and workspaces.

text: In a real early-stage startup, you are taking out the trash yourself. If you want a drink, you buy it. You build yoÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/k8tQGWH2nq
full_text:
In a real early-stage startup, you are taking out the trash yourself. If you want a drink, you buy it. You build your own desk.
This can actually be a fun part of startup life; it teaches you to take less for granted and creates a tangible sense of ownership in the company.

text: These all seem like small things, but creating a functioning, humane workplace for people to do great work can takeÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/7hmCQ9aYfX
full_text:
True story: We once wrapped an ethernet cable around the outside of our high-rise office building like a clothesline from the 19th to 18th floor to get internet to our sales team.
I bought the cable bulk from Home Depot and tried to pick a subtle color so we wouldn’t get caught.

text: 3) Big company Ã¢??startupsÃ¢?? start off with the existing infrastructure of a megacorp. The company provides snacks andÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/mcnZKCXRzc
full_text:
These all seem like small things, but creating a functioning, humane workplace for people to do great work can take a lot of time, thought, and resources.
Emulating the startup “garage” atmosphere inside of a big company is all of the glamour without all of the garbage.

text: Startups, on the other hand, have to put much more effort into building their teams. Every hire is from outside theÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/edwtBSu0U8
full_text:
4)
A big company “startup” product is sold and promoted with the resources of the big company behind it.
Even if you are a “just” a 30-person team, when you do Fast Company to show the cool thing you incubated, it’s with the implicit megaphone of a Google or Facebook behind you.

text:
4) A big company Ã¢??startupÃ¢?? product is sold and promoted with the resources of the big company behind it.

Even if yÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/wuZFoR1OT2
full_text:
You’ve got a field sales team ready to sell what you’ve created. A marketing/PR engine ready to promote it. The name, goodwill, and trust that your company has created with customers.
These are all incalculably valuable, and often forgotten or taken for granted.

text: YouÃ¢??ve got a field sales team ready to sell what youÃ¢??ve created. A marketing/PR engine ready to promote it. The namÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/50t1gOwbo0
full_text:
As someone who made a transition from a big “center of the tech world” company to founding a company, I didn’t realize how much I assumed that when we created new stuff, the world would pay attention to it.
No such luck. In the startup world, you have to hustle for every story.

text: 5) Hiring in a big company Ã¢??startupÃ¢?? is often more like a draft, where you get to pick the Ã¢??best & brightestÃ¢?? fromÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/LIhYBeyKUb
full_text:
5)
Hiring in a big company “startup” is often more like a draft, where you get to pick the “best & brightest” from other teams to rapidly fill your headcount.
Teams can quickly ramp to 30, 50, 100+ people, with plenty of money to pay them and loads of readily-available talent.

text: As someone who made a transition from a big Ã¢??center of the tech worldÃ¢?? company to founding a company, I didnÃ¢??t realÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/ymtAHVxsWJ
full_text: Startups, on the other hand, have to put much more effort into building their teams. Every hire is from outside the company. You have to sell people on your vision, the ambiguous role, that you will still be around to pay their salary and health care in six months.

text: All of this is not to say that Ã¢??innovation teamsÃ¢?? inside of big companies shouldnÃ¢??t exist, or that they are bad plaÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/uYT5EaEtp9
full_text:
Real startups naturally attract people willing to embrace the risk/ambiguity in return for bigger challenges, autonomy, faster learning, and more ownership/upside.
When I read megacorp resumes that say they work “in a startup,” I try not to judge. They don’t know how it sounds.

text: Real startups naturally attract people willing to embrace the risk/ambiguity in return for bigger challenges, autonÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/KWe6N3pE14
full_text:
All of this is not to say that “innovation teams” inside of big companies shouldn’t exist, or that they are bad places to work.
These teams might well be fun, with smart people and great perks. They may produce interesting products.
But they are certainly not a startup.

text:
Leaving a big company job for a startup can rejuvenate your career and make you love work again.Ã°???

But landing a stÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/Uqw6joZFqE
full_text:
Leaving a big company job for a startup can rejuvenate your career and make you love work again.💖
But landing a startup job requires relearning some things, especially if (like me) you logged years and years at Microgoogfaceforceazon.
Here are six things I wish I'd known:

text:
1) At a startup, you will probably make less money at first.

Yes, if you join the perfect startup early enough, yoÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/txF0dNn7Kv
full_text:
1)
At a startup, you will probably make less money at first.
Yes, if you join the perfect startup early enough, your equity may someday turn into a private island and 200 foot yacht. But, in the meantime, your take home pay is likely going to be a bit less than it is now.

text: The so-called Ã¢??golden handcuffsÃ¢?? that big companies give you in stock grants/bonuses that vest over time are becausÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/vryypRdnw9
full_text:
The so-called “golden handcuffs” that big companies give you in stock grants/bonuses that vest over time are because those companies need to overpay you in order to get you to stay.
Think about the metaphor for a second: You don't have to handcuff people to things they love.

text: You can make a great living at a startup of course, and growth stage startups in particular pay competitively and oÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/9LSzk8HRkD
full_text:
You can make a great living at a startup of course, and growth stage startups in particular pay competitively and often with fantastic benefits.
But if optimizing for the most take home cash is your #1 priority, keep your job. Seriously… it’s ok. Startups are not for everyone.

text: 2) About your resume: if youÃ¢??ve been at a big company for a long time, you really need to figure out what experiencÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/F4EQmbEZuh
full_text:
2)
About your resume: if you’ve been at a big company for a long time, you really need to figure out what experiences you’ve had that show depth outside of that company.
Wrote apps for an unfamiliar platform? Started a nonprofit? Ran a successful Kickstarter campaign? All great.

text:
3) HereÃ¢??s something it took me a long time to learn on the outside: say Ã¢??IÃ¢?? instead of Ã¢??we.Ã¢??

Working for @stevesiÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/I2bgSBRJmc
full_text:
When I left Microsoft after 16 years, I had worked on what seemed to me to be a dizzying array of roles and products. Within Microsoft, that was compelling.
To the external world, it was just 16 monolithic years at MSFT and everyone asked pointedly: why didn’t you leave sooner?

text: Also, leave off whatever Ã¢??high potentialÃ¢?? programs you were selected to, or awards you won inside of the megacorp.Ã¢?Â¦ https://t.co/qUMqQpB3xO
full_text:
Also, leave off whatever “high potential” programs you were selected to, or awards you won inside of the megacorp. Same with review scores.
Those don’t matter on the outside, and just show that you're still deeply entrenched in the value system of the company you're leaving.

text: When I left Microsoft after 16 years, I had worked on what seemed to me to be a dizzying array of roles and productÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/UZDdGpZboR
full_text:
3)
Here’s something it took me a long time to learn on the outside: say “I” instead of “we.”
Working for
@stevesi
at MSFT, I learned an incredibly important lesson about leading inside of a large team: always say “we did this” not “I did this.” Perfect advice for that situation.

text:
When interviewing, though, saying Ã¢??we did this" makes it hard to identify your personal contribution.

I find myselÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/DC9P9BFHht
full_text:
When interviewing, though, saying “we did this" makes it hard to identify your personal contribution.
I find myself talking to megacorp candidates trying to understand what did *they* do? What specific designs did they draw… what code did they write… what ideas were theirs?

text: But also, donÃ¢??t claim personal accomplishment for a team effort unless you provably did it. You probably didnÃ¢??t Ã¢??brÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/9zpFI1Sz6A
full_text:
But also, don’t claim personal accomplishment for a team effort unless you provably did it. You probably didn’t “bring AI to iOS” yourself.
You didn’t “create the Windows 7 kernel” or “increase S3’s scalability 400%” yourself.
Specify *your* actual contribution to the product.

text: This means if you work for Amazon, build something on DigitalOcean. Googler? Build with React. From Microsoft? GetÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/xgVT90kf6T
full_text:
4)
For devs: show true curiosity outside of your company’s stack. Your mastery of Google’s internal experimentation pipeline is not interesting outside of Google. If you are MSFT and I ask you if you’ve used Redis and you say “you mean Azure Redis Cache?”, that’s not a good sign.

text: 4) For devs: show true curiosity outside of your companyÃ¢??s stack. Your mastery of GoogleÃ¢??s internal experimentationÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/49M1mxtMMM
full_text:
This means if you work for Amazon, build something on DigitalOcean. Googler? Build with React. From Microsoft? Get into AWS.
The best big company devs we’ve hired are the ones with natural, proven technical curiosity outside of their company’s native stack, shown by actual work.

text:
5) Be a workerÃ¢?Â¦ and be prepared to show it.

Big companies are necessarily full of people whose primary job it is tÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/aTpDbhgeLw
full_text: Don’t say the reason you want to join a startup is “to have a chance to learn XYZ technology.” Learn and build with the tech you are curious about yourself… your company is not in control of your learning. Prove that you’re curious by actions, not words.

text: DonÃ¢??t say the reason you want to join a startup is Ã¢??to have a chance to learn XYZ technology.Ã¢?? Learn and build withÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/1HJgKXKOsd
full_text:
5)
Be a worker… and be prepared to show it.
Big companies are necessarily full of people whose primary job it is to carry information from one meeting to another, from one department to another. Middle managers and PMs, in particular, are often defined by this type of work.

text:
ThereÃ¢??s a whole world out here, free from the walls of your megacorp job.

Enter into it for the right reasons, andÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/e1pe0lmT89
full_text: Startups don’t have this kind of “info pusher” job. They can’t afford to, and they’re not big enough to need it. Everyone is responsible for making something, building product, owning decisions, selling something, hustling. You can’t just show up at the meeting and “seem senior.”

text:
DonÃ¢??t feel like you have to be on your back foot or defensive about your time at a megacorp.

It took me a year outÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/KhBkj7SFwP
full_text: Big company folks sometimes flame out at startups because this kind of individual work is not what they actually want. No judgment from me or anyone else if it’s not… be honest with yourself about the degree to which you want to be on the frontlines, making or selling things.

text: 6) Embrace the unique skills you developed in a big company. No one builds more reliable software at scale than AmaÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/KiIMU9qaGW
full_text:
6)
Embrace the unique skills you developed in a big company. No one builds more reliable software at scale than Amazon or Google… this knowledge can be a huge boon to a startup. Salesforce perfected solution-based selling; this may help scale your SaaS startup’s sales expertise.

text: Startups donÃ¢??t have this kind of Ã¢??info pusherÃ¢?? job. They canÃ¢??t afford to, and theyÃ¢??re not big enough to need it. EvÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/Dr1ENzGADG
full_text:
Don’t feel like you have to be on your back foot or defensive about your time at a megacorp.
It took me a year out of Microsoft to realize that so much of what I learned there was applicable in my new startup job—i just needed to learn to apply it in a different environment.

text: Big company folks sometimes flame out at startups because this kind of individual work is not what they actually waÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/tV7XN2rtqb
full_text:
There’s a whole world out here, free from the walls of your megacorp job.
Enter into it for the right reasons, and you'll find joining a startup to be truly transformative for your career and rejuvenating for your soul.
Prepare for it the right way, and you too can join us! 🙌

text: Today begins Women's History Month, and @eiwhalen threw down a challenge to #twitterstorians to tweet daily about aÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/jFvcnubQZB
full_text:
Today begins Women's History Month, and
@eiwhalen
threw down a challenge to
#twitterstorians
to tweet daily about a woman who made history.
So here begins my thread for the month -- others, please join in!

text: @eiwhalen 3/1: In class today I taught Charles Payne's extraordinary _I've Got the Light of Freedom_ so I'll startÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/a8XcL0ht0b
full_text: 3/1: In class today I taught Charles Payne's extraordinary _I've Got the Light of Freedom_ so I'll start with ELLA BAKER, the grassroots community organizer with the NAACP, SCLC, & SNCC, who fought the freedom struggle by tirelessly teaching participatory democracy.

text: @eiwhalen The Civil Rights Movement would have been very different & likely less effective, without her work. Ms. BÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/aJzvyMbQBp
full_text: The Civil Rights Movement would have been very different & likely less effective, without her work. Ms. Baker didn't have much faith in charismatic leaders or centralized institutions, but faith in communities learning how to to collectively advocate their interests.

text:
@eiwhalen Here's Payne's book: https://t.co/mR11DPo5yd

And also Barbara Ransby's biography: https://t.co/HdbQmk0Exk
url:
https://t.co/mR11DPo5yd

And also Barbara Ransby's biography:
full_text:
Here's Payne's book:
amazon.com/Ive-Got-Light-…
And also Barbara Ransby's biography:
amazon.com/Ella-Baker-Bla…

text: @eiwhalen 3/2: As teachers keep striking in West Virginia, remember Mary Harris Jones-Mother Jones-who called it "MÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/hMaT375pQL
full_text: 3/2: As teachers keep striking in West Virginia, remember Mary Harris Jones-Mother Jones-who called it "Medieval West Virginia"--"With its tent colonies on the bleak hills! With its grim men and women! When I get to the other side, I will tell God almighty about West Virginia!"

text: @eiwhalen An Irish immigrant, her husband & 4 children died of yellow fever. Afterwards, she took to the cause of lÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/mj3WRK2qTI
full_text: An Irish immigrant, her husband & 4 children died of yellow fever. Afterwards, she took to the cause of labor, from exploited children to impoverished worker families. She most famously organized mine workers, but also works in railroads, breweries, steel, and textiles.

text: @eiwhalen She lived up to her words of "Pray for the dead, and fight like hell for the living" -- becoming among thÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/i2rHf6m8xd
full_text:
She lived up to her words of "Pray for the dead, and fight like hell for the living" -- becoming among the most influential labor organizers of the early 20th century-when that meant a real risk of getting killed. Check out Elliot Gorn's great biography:
amazon.com/Mother-Jones-D…

text: @eiwhalen 3/3: Labor's still on my mind so today's woman who made history is Frances Perkins, whose 12 years as LabÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/C9HQzp1nK8
full_text: 3/3: Labor's still on my mind so today's woman who made history is Frances Perkins, whose 12 years as Labor Secretary during the Depression & WWII made her the longest-serving in history & the first woman cabinet member. But those firsts are nothing compared with what she did.

text: @eiwhalen Perkins began her career in teaching & social work, coming of age among Progressive Era attempts to allevÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/s3m7WroB0d
full_text: Perkins began her career in teaching & social work, coming of age among Progressive Era attempts to alleviate poverty & exploitative working conditions. She witnessed the Triangle Shirtwaist fire & the scores of women who plunged to their deaths-an event that galvanized her work.

text: @eiwhalen She worked her way up as a labor reformer in NY, eventually serving as head of the state's labor departmeÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/vpPdHXU1cN
full_text: She worked her way up as a labor reformer in NY, eventually serving as head of the state's labor department under FDR's governorship. When he headed to Washington in 1933, she joined him-on the condition he support her pro-labor, pro-union, pro-worker security efforts. He did.

text: @eiwhalen She managed the most popular New Deal program-the Civilian Conservation Corps-as well as the public worksÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/TK6GLBW1E3
full_text: She managed the most popular New Deal program-the Civilian Conservation Corps-as well as the public works program begun under the National Industrial Recovery Act. She helped launch the Federal Emergency Relief Administration to provide for those most desperate for aid.

text: @eiwhalen Perhaps most importantly, her Committee on Economic Security in 1934 drafted the legislation that becameÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/8jbjXsyTR0
full_text: Perhaps most importantly, her Committee on Economic Security in 1934 drafted the legislation that became the Social Security Act a year later, introducing old age pensions, unemployment benefits, and workers compensation.

text: @eiwhalen In 1938, she helped draft the Fair Labor Standards Act; for the first time permanently setting federal miÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/yqFvHzLftb
full_text: In 1938, she helped draft the Fair Labor Standards Act; for the first time permanently setting federal minimum wages, maximum hours, and a ban on child labor. She dealt with major strikes & labor conflict in the Depression & war, & later served on the US Civil Service Commission.

text: @eiwhalen There are a lot of biographies of Perkins, and much more on labor in Depression & war more generally, butÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/ShNAwFYMuo
full_text:
There are a lot of biographies of Perkins, and much more on labor in Depression & war more generally, but here's one of the most recent by biographer Kirstin Downey:
amazon.com/Woman-Behind-N…

text: 3/4: ItÃ¢??s #Oscars night! IÃ¢??m thinking about 1944Ã¢??s Best Actress winner, Ingrid Bergman, for her role in Ã¢??Gaslight.Ã¢??Ã¢?Â¦ https://t.co/04oAxDdB8h
full_text:
3/4: It’s
#Oscars
night! I’m thinking about 1944’s Best Actress winner, Ingrid Bergman, for her role in “Gaslight.” It’s about a manipulative husband who hides his crimes by making his wife think she is going insane. The term “gaslighting” has taken on a new relevance since 2016.

text: 3/5 [I know it's 3/7 but I'm trying to catch up] Ida B. Wells, born to enslaved parents in 1862 who became a crusadÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/weeQDBszrl
full_text:
3/5
[I know it's 3/7 but I'm trying to catch up] Ida B. Wells, born to enslaved parents in 1862 who became a crusading activist and journalist against lynching and for women's rights & suffrage
amazon.com/Ida-Sword-Camp…

full_text: Okay, since we're remembering the Holocaust, I'm going to tell a story about my grandfather. He was, by and large, a strange man who treated his children and wife poorly. And the reasons were complicated, and rooted in his time in the Army.

text: Before WWII my grandather was a recent medical school grad who wanted to be a plastic surgeon. He was the son of anÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/sSfz0vf9tr
full_text: Before WWII my grandather was a recent medical school grad who wanted to be a plastic surgeon. He was the son of an Italian immigrant who'd managed to get through school on his own dime, married a model (my grandmother was in Vogue, I'm told) and was all set to have a great life

text: He was somewhat isolationist, from what he'd told me. Didn't care about Europe or her problems, certainly didn't caÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/DrMoaYxbXQ
full_text: He was somewhat isolationist, from what he'd told me. Didn't care about Europe or her problems, certainly didn't care much about Jews. Typical stereotypes, saw them as greedy and money hungry. Didn't want to go over and fight. Then Pearl Harbor happened.

text: He ended up a doctor in the Army. He actually volunteered. Was so mad about the sneak attack. Thought he'd end up iÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/ctcc0SKeKg
full_text: He ended up a doctor in the Army. He actually volunteered. Was so mad about the sneak attack. Thought he'd end up in the Pacific, but that's not how things went. Served in North Africa, then Italy, before D-Day. (He spoke Italian and German so he was valuable.)

text: Of course he saw a lot of shit. Told me about watching men die on D-Day, being unable to do anything for them. ToldÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/duIBjvmCFX
full_text: Of course he saw a lot of shit. Told me about watching men die on D-Day, being unable to do anything for them. Told me about the slow, inexorable march through Europe, the push to defeat the Germans. Told it in a very clinical way, because it barely mattered to him.

text:
What mattered to him was what happened after they'd pushed the Germans far enough back. 

See, my grandfather was oÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/JnFLHboN2L
full_text:
What mattered to him was what happened after they'd pushed the Germans far enough back.
See, my grandfather was one of the first Americans to see a concentration camp. As a doctor, he was one of the first ones to treat the survivors. And it broke him.

text: I want you to imagine that man, sitting in a chair in the basement of his son's house some forty years after, stariÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/rzbRgsKoSW
full_text: I want you to imagine that man, sitting in a chair in the basement of his son's house some forty years after, staring off into space as he told his grandson about watching people die from starvation and dysentery. About trying to feed people and killing them.

text: For my grandfather, that moment was the whole war. The utter failure of his world to save those people. He was a doÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/8ztPRE8bLF
full_text: For my grandfather, that moment was the whole war. The utter failure of his world to save those people. He was a doctor and he couldn't save them. He came face to face with the industrialization of genocide and he simply broke, and remained broken for decades.

text: He came home and had kids (my father was the oldest, born in 1948) and never recovered from what he'd seen. He wentÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/DtJxgqNtMG
full_text: He came home and had kids (my father was the oldest, born in 1948) and never recovered from what he'd seen. He went into plastic surgery and was quite successful. He didn't love his wife anymore, or the children he had with her, or really anyone or anything. Nothing mattered.

text: The idea that people will try and tell you it wasn't real drove him insane. The idea that it could happen again herÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/yD4BneUxYx
full_text: The idea that people will try and tell you it wasn't real drove him insane. The idea that it could happen again here, that anyone could parrot the mad ideals that led to it, that his own relatives in Italy, his cousins had fought for fascism... he lived his life broken by it.

text: He didn't come home and put it aside, because he couldn't. I remember being a child sitting in the basement with hiÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/AJkTyED5Hw
full_text: He didn't come home and put it aside, because he couldn't. I remember being a child sitting in the basement with him while he shook and wept and told me these things that I was far too young to understand. Because somebody had to know, and his own son hated him.

text:
"I deserve it."

He had brown eyes. I remember them, the way they looked.

"I should have left them years ago."

ThÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/VZZeVLOSQg

"I deserve it."
He had brown eyes. I remember them, the way they looked.
"I should have left them years ago."
The Holocaust was a real thing. Never let anyone tell you different, or try and reframe it as anything other than genocide.

text: It was genocide against Jews, the Roma, homosexuals and it was waged in stages. Bergen-Belsen didn't spring up fromÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/dgeORqA0OP
full_text: It was genocide against Jews, the Roma, homosexuals and it was waged in stages. Bergen-Belsen didn't spring up from the ground like sown dragon's teeth. They started with restrictive laws, rhetoric, and grew. The oxygen that fueled that flame was the blind eyes the world turned.

text: These are the things that old man told me. While telling me about trying to feed a small Jewish girl and coming bacÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/FMRpAygEJK
full_text: These are the things that old man told me. While telling me about trying to feed a small Jewish girl and coming back to find her dead anyway. The smell of bodies and waste. "So thick in the air I could see it." That's the crop you grow when you sow these dragon's teeth. Dead kids

full_text: He told me that it was real. That it was death industrialized. That it was carried out right up until the end. That we... the USA... did nothing to stop it, when we could have. That people like him had even supported turning boatloads of Jews away in the 30's.

text:
I remember as much of it as I can for him because he's gone now. 

The Holocaust was real. He saw it. He told me. We can't ever forget.

text: So it's very common for writers to ask why agents don't give feedback. The answer, usually, is that we're busy--butÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/2WcCX3SP2Q

full_text: So we get (I did the math awhile ago) an average of 39.98 queries a workday times 5 days = 2,158 pages/month from queries. I probably read an average of 2/10 of the included pages, so that's 1 query + 2 pages times 2,158 = 6,474 pages/month.

text: For the 2/10, keep in mind that there are a LOT of "Dear Sirs" and "I have published the next bestseller please takÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/Fq7i8JZwUg

text: With a 7.5% request rate (2.99/day times 5 (M-F) times 4 (weeks in month) = 59.97 manuscripts. If I read 20 pages eÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/WqVmtbAMfD
full_text: With a 7.5% request rate (2.99/day times 5 (M-F) times 4 (weeks in month) = 59.97 manuscripts. If I read 20 pages each on average (keep in mind many are picture books), that's 1,199.4 pages of requested material/month + 6,474 unrequested = 7,673.4 pages a month of submissions.

text: Now, I strongly suspect the 7.5 percent is high (this was calculated maybe two years ago?). But even say it's 3 perÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/e4smiYL8cG
full_text: With a 7.5% request rate (2.99/day times 5 (M-F) times 4 (weeks in month) = 59.97 manuscripts. If I read 20 pages each on average (keep in mind many are picture books), that's 1,199.4 pages of requested material/month + 6,474 unrequested = 7,673.4 pages a month of submissions.

text: So, yes, we are busy. No, we are not sitting here cackling like "Haha, I know exactly how to fix her manuscript, anÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/H3lroxNUT4
full_text: Now, I strongly suspect the 7.5 percent is high (this was calculated maybe two years ago?). But even say it's 3 percent now, that's 1.1994 requests a day, times 5 (M-F), times 4 (weeks) times 20 (average pages read) = 479.76 requested pages read/month.

text: Do I try to keep up? Yes! Do I achieve inbox zero? No! Inbox 100? No. Do I try to keep in touch about delays? Yes!Ã¢?Â¦ https://t.co/ILAoVt9FE1
full_text: So, yes, we are busy. No, we are not sitting here cackling like "Haha, I know exactly how to fix her manuscript, and I'm not telling her! Why? Because! Bwahahahaa!" Much as I receive a lot of correspondence to this effect.

text: I suspect a lot of agents have similar inboxes (I've heard everywhere from 10-50 average queries a day). Many probaÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/7etmhwsoui
full_text: Do I try to keep up? Yes! Do I achieve inbox zero? No! Inbox 100? No. Do I try to keep in touch about delays? Yes! Do I always manage to check in with everyone when things take a long time? Sadly, no. Am I constantly feeling guilt about making so many people wait? Yes. Yes, I am.

text: Keep in mind that I don't get all day to read submissions. I actually spend more time on clients, meetings, my ownÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/rjAwaH7nc6
full_text: I suspect a lot of agents have similar inboxes (I've heard everywhere from 10-50 average queries a day). Many probably have lower request rates (perhaps closer to 1-2%). Many have assistants, interns, teams. However, I suspect that 0% of agents enjoy making writers wait.

text: Things I could do to be faster (of course I've considered them!): 1) Not respond to queries. This would save aboutÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/vQhoeNg72g
full_text: Keep in mind that I don't get all day to read submissions. I actually spend more time on clients, meetings, my own submissions, contracts, and the like. I'm pretty much reading during downtime--evenings, weekends, subway, train trips, plane trips, waiting in line.

text: 2) Let readers make all of the query requesting decisions for me. Now, if you know me at all, you know I am waaaaayÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/scpdO0eP6m
full_text: Things I could do to be faster (of course I've considered them!): 1) Not respond to queries. This would save about 30 seconds from each, times 39.98 times 5 (M-F) times 4 (weeks) divided by 60 (convert to minutes) = 399.8 minutes a month, or 6.6633 hours.

text: 4) Drink more coffee, sleep less. I'm up to two coffees a day, one tea. Just tried the Starbucks app for the firstÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/ciKumLxE3h
full_text:
2)
Let readers make all of the query requesting decisions for me. Now, if you know me at all, you know I am waaaaayyyyyy too much of a control freak to let that happen. I read all queries myself. 3) Manuscripts--same.

text: 5) Give Up Everything Fun And Just Be An Efficient Human, Dammit: Believe me, I've tried. Strangely, this makes meÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/0IkwhHkvOD
full_text:
4)
Drink more coffee, sleep less. I'm up to two coffees a day, one tea. Just tried the Starbucks app for the first time today (it was weird--too easy). I think that's enough. Otherwise I'll just run around all day. And bad things happen fast if I don't sleep.

text: So, that's where I'm at. Do I still expect lots of "Agents are so mean because they don't give feedback" emails? YeÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/mHkoMVLYRa
full_text:
5)
Give Up Everything Fun And Just Be An Efficient Human, Dammit: Believe me, I've tried. Strangely, this makes me miserable and worse at my job. I do need some degree of happiness in my life to be able to function as a creative person--which an agent is. Always. So. That's out.

text: And there's one now. Cool.
full_text: So, that's where I'm at. Do I still expect lots of "Agents are so mean because they don't give feedback" emails? Yes. And the check-ins at three weeks? And the "I am so tired of agents being SO UNPROFESSIONAL and NOT GIVING ANY FEEDBACK" tweets? Yes.

text: And I get genuine energy and pleasure out of connecting people. I think all agents do. Makes me feel like what I doÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/04mddyor1T
full_text: And there's one now. Cool.

text: You may be asking, "Jessica! Why in the world are you doing side projects when you have all of this happening?" TheÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/GuEYgD3365
full_text: You may be asking, "Jessica! Why in the world are you doing side projects when you have all of this happening?" The answer is that, for me, it's easier to keep moving. A change, for me, even if just a setting (office vs coworking space vs home) is more restorative than a rest.

text: Do I suspect some agents just manage to be faster through...magic? Better systems? Better coffee? Not sleeping? WorÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/ZpRIJmqCoq
full_text: And I get genuine energy and pleasure out of connecting people. I think all agents do. Makes me feel like what I do is meaningful. And that means so much more than numbers could.

text: I disagree with this line of reasoning. First, the line between a Ã¢??restriction of libertyÃ¢?? and Ã¢??deprivation of libeÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/GO8M2j3eSK
full_text: I disagree with this line of reasoning. First, the line between a ‘restriction of liberty’ and ‘deprivation of liberty’ is finely drawn in European human rights jurisprudence ‘as a matter of degree or intensity, but not one of nature or substance’ (Guzzardi).

text: Thirdly, liberty must be capable of being realized in practice. Where exercising liberty has considerable coerciveÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/gRxkIvVfgy
full_text: Thirdly, liberty must be capable of being realized in practice. Where exercising liberty has considerable coercive results, this constitutes a restriction of liberty in actuality. Assange can hardly be said to be voluntarily ‘self-confined’.

full_text: Fourthly, the fact that Assange is deliberately resisting arrest doesn’t resolve this issue, as this would be to argue that liberty is a right contingent on his co-operation.

text: Fifth, liberty is not a privilege gained for good behavior, it is a right which demands justifications from those seeking its restriction.
full_text: Fifth, liberty is not a privilege gained for good behavior, it is a right which demands justifications from those seeking its restriction.

text: Having said all this, the grounds for determining whether a deprivation of liberty is arbitrary is a separate questÃ¢?Â¦ https://t.co/z1ItDIfKCr
full_text: Having said all this, the grounds for determining whether a deprivation of liberty is arbitrary is a separate question. This rests, inter alia, on considerations of proportionality. This is where the WGAD could have been clearer.
